articles.headline: In Public Education, Edge Still Goes to Rich
articles.snippet: Funding for many school districts comes from local property taxes, which skews the playing field between wealthy and poor students early on.
articles.abstract: Funding for many school districts comes from local property taxes, which skews the playing field between wealthy and poor students early on.
articles.lead_paragraph: “There aren’t many things that are more important to that idea of economic mobility — the idea that you can make it if you try — than a good education,” President Obama told students at the State University of New York in Buffalo in August.

articles.headline: China’s Leaders Confront Economic Fissures
articles.snippet: As it prepares for a critical policy meeting, the Communist Party faces a persistent problem: Jobs abound in China, but not the kind young graduates want.
articles.abstract: As it prepares for a critical policy meeting, the Communist Party faces a persistent problem: Jobs abound in China, but not the kind young graduates want.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — The two-story employment complex here, like job centers across China, is crowded with educated young people who are trying to figure out their futures in a country where the job market still prizes assembly-line workers willing to labor monotonous hours on backless stools.

articles.headline: MF Global Customers Will Recover All They Lost
articles.snippet: A federal bankruptcy court judge approved a plan on Tuesday that would close the remaining shortfall for some 20,000 customers.
articles.abstract: A federal bankruptcy court judge approved a plan on Tuesday that would close the remaining shortfall for some 20,000 customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after $1.6 billion vanished from their accounts, MF Global’s customers are now all but assured to collect every last penny.

articles.headline: New York Is Investigating Advisers to Pension Funds
articles.snippet: Benjamin Lawsky, the state’s financial services regulator, wants to know if any advice is clouded by incentives or conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, the state’s financial services regulator, wants to know if any advice is clouded by incentives or conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Public pensions in New York State have some of the most reliable funding in the country, but what happens to the money once it is in the pension system can be less clear-cut.

articles.headline: After SAC Plea, Fellow Funds May Pay
articles.snippet: More active regulators and stricter financial laws have forced hedge funds to spend millions of dollars to stay out of trouble.
articles.abstract: More active regulators and stricter financial laws have forced hedge funds to spend millions of dollars to stay out of trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: In striking its $1.2 billion settlement with SAC Capital Advisors, the government set a record for insider trading penalties. For the hedge fund industry, the hidden costs of the deal are even bigger.

articles.headline: Terry McAuliffe, Democrat, Is Elected Governor of Virginia in Tight Race
articles.snippet: Terry McAuliffe, a longtime Democratic fund-raiser, won by two points after outraising Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the attorney general, nearly two to one.
articles.abstract: Terry McAuliffe, a longtime Democratic fund-raiser, won by two points after outraising Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the attorney general, nearly two to one.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYSONS CORNER, Va. — Terry McAuliffe, a longtime Democratic fund-raiser and ally of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, was elected governor of Virginia on Tuesday, narrowly defeating the state’s conservative attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, and confirming Virginia’s evolution as a state increasingly dominated politically by the Democratic-leaning Washington suburbs.

articles.headline: Despite Fumbles, Obama Defends Health Care Law
articles.snippet: As Democrats get jittery over the troubled rollout of the health care law, President Obama traveled to Texas to defend it, in the largest state to refuse to participate.
articles.abstract: As Democrats get jittery over the troubled rollout of the health care law, President Obama traveled to Texas to defend it, in the largest state to refuse to participate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — President Obama strongly defended his signature health care law on Wednesday in the largest state that has refused to participate, as rattled Senate Democrats called for changing or delaying key parts of the new health coverage.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jonathan Weisman
